keyTakeAways: A Picasso painting, 'Still Life with Guitar' (1919), went missing during transport to a temporary exhibition in Granada, Spain.
The work was insured for 600,000 euros ($700,000) and was under video surveillance throughout the delivery and unpacking process.
All artworks were delivered in a single movement via van, transported to a freight elevator, and then moved to the exhibition hall under surveillance.
The painting was discovered missing during unpacking on Monday, October 13, 2025, after staff verified the delivery and completed the transfer process.
Spanish police have launched an investigation and have reported the artwork to international stolen artworks databases.
Historical context shows that Picasso’s works have been a frequent target of theft, with previous recoveries in 2019, 2021, and 2024.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 1919 gouache painting by Pablo Picasso titled 'Still Life with Guitar' went missing during its scheduled delivery to a temporary exhibition at the CajaGranada Cultural Center in Granada, Spain. The painting, insured for 600,000 euros ($700,000), was part of a secure transport chain involving a van, video surveillance, and a freight elevator transfer. Staff discovered it missing during unpacking on Monday, October 13, 2025, despite no incidents being recorded over the weekend. Spanish police have launched an investigation and have added the work to international stolen artworks databases. The incident reflects a broader pattern of theft targeting Picasso’s works, with past recoveries in Greece, Belgium, and the Netherlands, demonstrating the global risk and value of his art.
title: Picasso painting goes missing en route to exhibition
